bookes hath bene alreadie set forth answere conteining maintenaunce creditte excellent minister elder god church malitious slaunderer hath sought deface staie simple reader till master charkes booke come forth hath also bene printed set forth doctor fulke briefe confutation sundrie cauills quarrel vttered diuerse papist writinges speciallie censurer booke defense whereby parte vnhonest dealing displayed discredite defender shame papist neuerthelesse vnderstanding master charke minded 〈◊〉 set forth answere although haue 〈◊〉 written defender hath 〈◊〉 wholl booke promiseth haue thought amisse write shorte treatis 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 matter doctrine especially controuersie betweene charke censurer either omitting breiflie touching point handled large two 〈◊〉 book neither thinke charkes staying misliked diuerse cause first auoyd confusion might ensue defender replic vpon answere first parte confutation second parte finished published secondlie auoyd misunderstanding diuerse pointes touched first parte may large otherwise handled latter parte vpon vew whereof master charke would change answere last lest replying reioyning vpon first parte might occasion latter parte neuer handled reason perhaps better knowne vnto himselfe indifferent reader may gather expedient staie vntill see wholl charge aduersarie orderly seasonablie may publish answere altogeather purpose taken inhande three tall fellowes step forth vpon bulwarke defense corrector printe setter forth booke graunde captaine defender himselfe corrector commeth forth parte stoppe gappe emptie place page reall 〈◊〉 nowne heretike presuming 〈◊〉 without author knowledge wise man belike made priuie gramaticall trifle whereas weeneth reading author treatise man shall see moste point verified master charke companion fouly beguiled wise man seeth pointes newlie deuised declension throughly verified author complices hath shewed himselfe one case proude maleperte lyar obstinate seditious atheist 〈◊〉 hereunto impudent heretike malitious traytor man simple cannot yet perfectlie holde pointes owne treatise yet answeres confutation thereof acknowledge verified like proue nowne declension thus owlie corrector hauing shotte bolte bulwarke euil happe contrarie winde caried backe selfe owne freinds retireth corner doth appeare sauing note negligence bewraying declare first time ouerseene life haue done master better seruise imploied time spent deuising grammatication occupied diligentlie office correction setter forth booke hath next place writing epistle master charke minister termeth indeede church god england woulde acknowledge publishing thing recited saunders bristow allen wicked wholl parte whether doth present acknowledge maiestie true lawful queene pretensed queene depriued possession crowne onelie de facto answereth first medleth neither fro answere requireth may answere second saith question dependeth vpon fact pius quintus whereof iudge therefore refuseth answere edmund campian answered argument flie indifferent kinde triall haue bene openly challenged doctor fulke conclude controuersies request protestation retentiue bristowes motiues religion betweene v strict forme syllogismes owne ease clearnes certainty iudgement rea sonable request refuse yealde vnto hath protested god world shew selues thereby enemy trueth flie light dare abide triall yet foure yeares day none hath aduentured easie certaine necessary trial cannot refuse wil haue trueth thought stand side let wise men iudge therefore whether refuse kinde quiet triall whether seditious kinde triall would haue appeared campians challenge although person contemptible yeares grauitie learning honestie make proude chalenge learned wise church common welth england yet brought light conferred withall diuerse graue learned men tried defense owne treatise god wot quickly found none familiar alwaies knew bold challenge able defend himselfe ready cauill like childish sophister answere like sober deuine simple ignorant campians impudencie wherein chieflie excelied repressed time euen opinion euerie man albeit vanquished yet last seemed cleane ouerthrowne shamefull foile would faine haue thought haue outfaced difference place praie betweene opponent respondent stooles equall height would haue fooles imagine belike charke sat loft throne seauen stepps higher campian meane prate high place gay apparell men maie see master charke daielie gorgeouslie araied turneth eies men vppon waie euer goeth el campian smale cause feare gaie apparell trueth apparell colour blacke matter wollen making common sorte minister london commonly vse weare campian bene stripped rugge gowne whereunder ruffianlike garment hidde would haue appeared much gayer apparell matter colour fashion master charke euer seene weare since came ministerie neuertheles gowne could hide spot hat daie yet time conference certaine seene rest iesuiticali robe ridde cheapside towards tower london therefore mee thinkes neede haue spoken master charkes gaie apparell sesquipedalia verba greate word foote halfe long lest master campian might outfaced present could obserue affectation o wordes weight matter bare downe chargeth luther opinion confesseth sometimes held afterward recanteth concerning licensing wiues lie neighbour husband naturall infirmitie hable partes say seemeth reasonable defense false dealing mary say word immediately follow luther declare would doe worsse would compell poore husbandes graunt wiues libertie el would tugge locke heade anie shameles see afterward answere defense large dealing c luther declare opinion word following say must needes confes great ouersight master charke lest shameles dealing luther meaning whole scope place plaine giue wife licence lie man band wedlocke continuing compell insufficient husband deuorced wife cannot haue lawfull remedie incontinency companie plaie papist graine thus exclame master charks false dealing phrase tugging lock dutch prouerb signifying inforcement vse owne word hath man anie conscience trow vrge colour vnhonest false accusation verily bene better haue held peace shalbe hereafter discouered slaunder vntruely vse deceit vse false plaie selfe impudentlie another example false dealing bring controuersie whether concupiscense regenerate without consent sinne master chark sore oppressed many place saint augustine auctoritie brought censurer findeth reliefe credit reader forge place saint augustine contrarie deceaue reader foisteth word sinne reciting word thus concupiscense forgiuen baptisme sinne addition word sinne matter seemeth stand cleere side cannot excused ignorance sheweth open wilfull malice man hasty iudgement peraduenture may excuse addition printer fault neither ignorance malice take moste hardly master chark purposely adde word sinne vnto augustine text yet strict translation neede alowable manifest saint augustine meaning addition word explication sense neither forging foisting impudentlying sir setter forth say findeth none reliefe credit reader adde word sinne augustine text immediatly pretended forgerie bringeth cleere place saint augustine doth expressly affirme concupiseense euen haue spirit god sinne argueth needed al forge foist hauing saint augustine word euident side findeth onely another farr better reliefe credit trueth could looke gaine bene disposed vse false dealing master charkes wordes saint augustine place making sinne regenerate without consent expounded himselfe afterward saying concupis cense forgiuen baptisme sinne imputed sinne cleere proofe hereof another booke saieth plainly sinne shewing occasion saying citeth place large cont iul lib 5 cap 3 wordes concupiscense flesh good spirit lusteth sinne disobedience regiment minde saith cleerer proofe probable word sinne formet text added lest wise deceaue addition confesse cleare parte added word plaine meaning saint augustine yet subiect cauilling expressed take awaie al colour wrangling terme ioyneth moste cleere proofe saint augustine iudgement plaine concupiscense regenerate sinne owne nature although forgiuen imputed sinne sense manifest concupiscense regenerate sinne sinne forgiuen sinne imputed therefore although sense man may truely say sinne forgiuen adulterie sinne sinne imputed sinne guiltines remoued 〈◊〉 remission couering imputing god mercy satisfaction christ yet followeth sinne owne nature damnable mercy hath made remissible sin forgiuen adultety like cannot properly called sinne pardoned cleane contrary doth follow necessity euen cōcupiscens forgiuen regenerate yet remaineth vertue indifferent thing euil thing augustine el confesseth yet sinne able condemne imputed pardoned therefore except wil say sinne forgiuen imputed ceaseth sinne owne nature concupiscense regenerate sin although forgiuen imputed matter inough time seing handled large hereafter plainly shewed saint augustine although sense say concupiscense sinne yet another sense doth plainly affirme sinne would condemne vnto death satisfied christ remitted vnto regenerate third example purpose deceaue hauing hand censure collen selfe reporteth diuerse vntruthes iesuites gotuisus concealing name quoting onely censura coloniensis sure cannot seene england andomitting canisius author gotuisus doth likewise cite may red euery man bare surmise without sufficient reason vphold two citeth one ergo seeketh deceaue censure collen common england canisius catechisme although master chark set forth first booke sold shop yet many study seemeth chuse cite like greater authoritie among papist done consent wholl vniuersity toucheth neerely gotuisus beelie iesuites sufficiently master chark without blushing falsifie wordes make odious gotuisus wordes iesuites say scripture nose wax master chark saith wordes scripture nose wax quarrell obiected first censurer answered charke reply protesting first set downe word meaning hath nothing varied therfro sense word scripture nose wax scripture nose wax seing man would dreame transsubstantiation al reasonable men vnderstand semblans likenes although note similitude expressed therefore appeareth purpose deceauing citing gotuisus paiua andradius also excusing crime kemnitius confesseth father collen apte similitude called nose wax pighius leaden rule lesbian building master charke sheweth whose purpose prooue vnapt vnworthie similitude therfore hath offered wrong iesuits censurers collen vsed fraude deceiue reader concerning behauiour towards campian tower london el mean greatly stand vpon cannot imagine colour set vpon slaunder yet somewhat must say el burst spight first inciuility wordes vttered campian booke blasphemous heretiks arrant traitor haue authoritie bloodie butcher god saint haue power require reuerenced euen whome possible meanes persecute abuse may vngentle word spoken though halfe much deserue heare complaine forsooth greate inciuilitie vsed toward ceusure noted reply hath answered therefore generall charge neede make none generall answere nothing contemptuous vsage learned man open audience surely learning goeth low among english papist campian made learned man euen lothsomnes often commended learning whome acknowledge learning honesty either priuy study trial knowledge must needes confes wasin much arrogancie learning contemptuous vsage pray lay master charks charge barbarous threatening crueltie minde hath put execution vppon man simple belecue slaunder hath chark put crueltie punishment iustice either vpon campian execution cam pians punishment greater cause thereof nay verily maie thinke probably lest wise may saie boldly greatest friendes papist much greater cause campians death minister england knowing proude stomach arrogant disposition man doth serue anie protestant turne whether fewer signes number maie called sacrament seeing protestant agree thing themselues set forth scripture visible signes grace inuisible name selfe sacrament sense speake saie 2 3 4 7 sacrament vsed diuersitie therefore terme vsed scripture therefore ariseth anie interpretation peruerse vnderstanding scripture answerer would haue seeme let v heare example martin luther saith denied testimonie man besides himselfe beginneth thus number sacrament principiò neganda mihisunt septem sacramenta tantúm tria pro tempore ponenda first must denie seauen come triall though catholikes would haue come councell nice nothing might haue beene therein determined pleased arius councell constantinople nothing might haue beene concluded macedonius would allow cause thought cleare iust would haue praied fire might come downe heauen example helias destroy samaritanes resused luk 9 receiue master christ otherwise heretikes weere reprooued yet knew forgotten spirit yet reiected heretikes contention sharpe betweene paull barnabas act 5 fault betweene yet holie apostle saint ierome misliked manie immoderat vehemencie speech rusfinus good catholike himselfe yea excused heat saint augustine vigilantius iouinian handleth hardlie termes cause either deserue although one fault sawe seedes superstition idolatrie sowing better yet saint paul barnabas ierome hereby noted heretikes railing saie foule scurrilitie protestant vse ordinarilie v among selues dissent dare auow proper ancetora onelie tell v call railing foule scurrilitie except meane verie odious termes lawfull tollerable railing foule scurrilitie v onelie accompt v heretikes must accompt trifling sophisters conuince v railing bring none argument wholl matter contro uersie betweene v namelie whether heretikes yet dare auow railing foule scurrility protestantes vse onelie agree v also proper v ancetors vn derstand none heretiks othe modesty papistes among whome one person found euer vsed railing scurrilitie true dare auow propertie heretikes whome take good examine reason would prooue railing proper vnto gospeller terme thereby easilie take scantling diuersitie spirit popish catholikes first mouth speaketh according aboundance heart trew sense spoken sauiour christ wickednesse first bred heart breake forth mouth followeth thereof conclude saie meane man maie knowne speach wickednes euerie hypocrite might appeare talke vntrue saint peter said vnto simon magus vpon onelie speech saie see thee verie gall bitternes c yet railing speech simon magus vttered dissembled speech plainlie professed desirous buie gift holie ghost last al onelie speach text saith offered act 8 mony march andise otherwise onelie word reported saint luke sufficient discouer great wickednes heart giue vnto also power vpon whomsoeuer laie handes maie receiue holie ghost might haue bene thought vpon onelie speech simon latelie baptized desirous haue beene minister dispensation holie ghost benefit god church graunt apostle profered monie also couetousnes wicked blasphemous opinion holie ghost plainlie discouered shew selfe therefore man mightie scripture bring better example proofe one onelie speech sometime maie sufficientlie conuicted wickednes hart peter simon magus onelie speech vsed speech vsed selfe able discouer heart spake matter greater controuersie betwixt v perhaps better exercised el like finde feeble argument behalfe proceede saie scripture plaine point point man maie knowne alwaies speech maie sometime thereby abundantlie conuinced doubt well saith scripture rom 8 hath spirit christ appertaineth christ true spirit adoption also sheweth selfe fruites mortification renouation hereof maie conclude thatall thinges haue spirit christ perfect neuer offended wordes whomesoeuer appeereth anie thing proceedeth spirite christ best manie thing therefore iudged void spirit christ therefore maie see sound diuinitie teach well vnderstand scripture vpon conclude followeth consider quiet calme sober spirit christ godlie christian beginning furious reprochfull vnclean spirit sathan heretikes time time compare writing partes daie maie easilie take ascantling diuersitie spirites verilie shall found hard matter made demonstration notwithstanding acknowledge quiet calme sober spirit christ christian yet confesse scripture plentifull prooue christ apostle wicked obstinate enemy trueth vsed hott vehement sharpe speech haue trueth side maie vse like like cause example vehemencie speech cause easilie discerned neither scantling right taken thereby kinde speaches moste parte accompted furious reprochfull vncleane vttered malice trueth spoken zeale falsehood maie wel stand quiet calme sober spirit christ yet also certaine vncleane reprochfull scurrilous speaches serue much describe falsehood sinne detestation thereof seeme themselues bewraie hatred intemperate heate vse person case commendable reprooued whether found papistes protestantes hierome man hurting bodelie health immoderate rigour austere life bringeth natural life daunger yet doe imbrace hierome member true church christ whoe trusted merite chaistisment onelie mercie god christ giuen sufficientlie tenne commaundements keeping good simplicitie plaine faith enough saluation especiallie laie men common people without anie new imposition moste greeuous burden according saying christ thou wilt enter life keep commaundements neither anie thing worth said people doe voluntarilie take vpon whipping without commaundement found therevpon doe licentiouslie contemne god apostle votum paupertatis vouerunt wordes dixerunt enim potentes illi ecce no dimisimus omnia secuti sumus te hoc votum potentissimi vouerunt sed vnde hoc eis nisi abillo de quo continuò dictum est dans votum vouenti mightie said behold haue left followed thee vowe mightie vowed whence came thie whome saide immediately geuing vow 〈◊〉 haue prooued apostle leauing thing follow christ renouncing propertie good except case could reteine doe seruice christ wherein beleeue obstinate heretike sentence pope iohn 23 declared al obstinat heretikes affirmed christ disciple haue nothing priuate proper condemned also glosse friar peter minorite incouraged certaine couent third order follow pouerty christ number many condemned burned platin ioan 23 doctrine doth agree looke vnto one greatly deceiued conclude vse al wordlie blessing lawfull well charge master charke minister allure dandle smooth men serue owne bellie c slaunder needeth confutation seeing open zealous preaching repentance people whereas men neither taking anie charge soules vpon receiuing anie tithe commodity thing charke doth reader may iudge whether stand daunger sentence charke saith eating sinnes people meaneth iesuits chiefly giue pardon money iesuits sometimes marchants wherein may pope eate sinnes people although haue benefice meane charge soules tithe taking sure liue angells food neither maintained altogether pure almes artificiall kinde cousonage vnder pretence restitution predeceslours pharisies vnder pretext long praiers deuoured house poore widowes man eat sinnes people haue benefice master charke daunger sentence neither hath charge soules tithe commoditie vnderstand matter whether paull third paull fourth first allow sect iesuites trifling matter worth strife sufficient master charkes reporte paull fourth confirme reason beleeue andradius credit kemnitius haue litle prosequute fruitles contention fift section entituled luther doctrine master charke first chargeth plainevntrueth saie doth contemptuouslie contumeliouslie cal loialas souldier doth neither honour disdaine anie way answer call souldier charge mumme whereas doth vnioint two argument manifestlie discouer insufficiencie denie made argumentes whereby acknowledge brought matter life laiolas luther vainlie slaunders papistes luther life think must credited matter fact though testimonie enimies must needes taken matter fact obstinate enemy gospell care feare either damnation open shame world inuent brute abroade moste impudent slaunders professours trueth concerning sleidans eleuen thousand lie wise man laugheth heare number one sleydan protestant hauing publike recordes writing iustifie storie could yet write eleuen thousand lie papistes affirme possible trow coclaeus hosius lindanus xanctes staphilus bolsec like papistes might write eleuen score lie luther zuinglius oecolampadius caluine beza rest concerning reporte prateolus luther begotten deuill saie master charke greatlie bewraieth fasehoode haue set downe reporte prateolus vnperfectlie praise modestie blame bolde impudencie william charke saying auoucheth auoucheth doth william charke faie prateolus doth auouch wordes slaunder laid downe martin luther begotten deuill confesse prateolus reporteth doth deede coclaeus cocleus men writing whether prateolus himselfe doth credit altogether skilleth slaunder among laieth downe luther fauoureth reporte farre woulde haue seeme credible saying auoucheth master chark speaketh one whit let reader therefore iudge bewraieth falsehood point vppon whome reproch bolde impudencie maie iustlie laid master charke sheweth great fullie impudencie beleeue making mention foule matter whereupon least remaineth shamefull suspicion deede triumph slaunderers cannot kill stroke yet leaue scarre wound healed although slaunder matter impossible leaueth suspition anie man head hath anie witte vnderstanding discouereth malice follie inuenters monstrous slaunders yet affirme probabilitie thing seemeth haue beene great day erasmus beleeued go asfarre beyond modestie author prateolus ere charged master charke runne wordes adhans historiam alludere alicubi erasmum non est à vero alienum story altogether vnlikelie straunge trueth erasmus doth place allude saith erasmus beleeue able prooue erasmus obiect speech erasmus onelie certaine vncleane speech complaineth vniustlie charged saith impudencie denie ludouicus viues vpon place sir cauiller thing question whether foule spirites maie abuse body lewd woman beside authoritie saint augustine standeth moste vpon testimony haue testimonie wierus man verie expert matter maketh reporte diuers nunnes abused vncleane spirites yea diuers nunnery manie dealt namelie notable nunnerie border de praest dae lib 3 c 9 tertiae editionis prouince collene deuill likenes dogge daie time seene fall vppon moste beastlie manner 26 yeares agoe also nunnerie nazareth collen anno 1564 nunnes filthie manner cap 11 suffered illusion oftentimes presence sight manie matter controuersie whether luther begotten deuill deniall master chatke doth stand becuase impossible although deuill abuse bodie woman yet man borne gotten illusion neither augustine affirmeth ludouicus viues dare auouch deuill begette childe seemeth would draw argument prooue probabilitie luther conception deuillish abusement bolde saie worthie whipt schooles philosopher phisitians diuines dare abide end oppose saint augustine ludouicus viues touching matter thunderbolte saie master charke denieth stoutlie confidentlie knowe trueth master charke saith selfe vncredible saie luther stroken thunderbolte would haue taken awaie life lefte marke behinde neuertheles williustifie saying testimonie malancthon saith suffeted great terror yeare lost com panion slaine know chaunce luther owne confession called terrours heauen feare death vowed frier yet neither doe prooue either ouerthrowne striken thunderbolte reportes lindane prateolus like cannot enforce v beleeue sought meanes deface person doctrine luther whether ouerthrowne lightning prateolus saith feare seeing fellow flaine vowed superstitious vow greatlie materiall deuill cried mouth hold still verie fable vntill bring better proofe report luther aduersaries lindane fellowes ribaudrie termes luther coping nunne blasphemous scoffing ofhis lying nunne lord cōmit vengeance instituter holie matrimonie many auncient father iudged vnlawfull vowed person marrie denied parte vnderstood maried necessitie wantones made vowes aduisedly rashlie voluntarilie compulsion could conteine vowed virginitie haue shewed plaine testimony saint hierome epiphanius come nine article doctrine haue charged luther iustlie shall see first affirmed luther teach sinne incredulitie neither man damne himselfe doe mischeefe except refuse beleeue master hanmer answereth sinnes proceade roote incredulitie al good workes roote faith vnderstand bring contradiction master charkes doth pronounce wordes matter reporte open vntruth doe thing bring defense luther saieth absolutely comparison sinne vnbeleefe sauiour christ sayth pharisies blinde haue sinne ioh 9 41 obstinate iewes come spoken vnto haue sinne done workes among could doe haue ioh 15 22 14 sinnes luther meaning therefore vnbeleefe greatest onelie sinne damneth man sinns forgiuen beleeueth baptized according promise god secondlie luther speaketh expresselie christian baptized say simplie man saith sianes great soeuer sate doe mischeefe blasphemous collection man cannot leese saluation would neuer faine c may doe fall incredulitie luther himselfe three wordes sheweth farre meaning answere gatherer errours doctrine delt honestlie said baptizatum etiam volentem c baptized man though willing cannot leese saluation luther answereth quia fides tollis omnia peccara facit volentem non pecca rom 1 faith taketh awaie sinnes maketh man willing sinne euen booke de captiuitate bab addeth condition doe fraudulentlie vnbeleefe vnderstood rightlie doth often expiicate himselfe full comfort troubled conscience yet giueth bridle sinne carnall libertie therfore howsoeuer wrest wordes meaning shew yourselfe lesse writeth vppon wordes text vnfaithful depart let departe brother sister bondage subiect hoc locus paulus saith fidelem coniugatum sententiam pro illo ferendo liberat vbi infidelis compar discesserit aut concedere non vult vt christum sequatur ei que copiare facit iterum cum alio matrimonium contrahendi quòd verò hic diuus paulus de ethnico compare dicit idem de falso christiano intelligendum est v si alter coniugum alterum ad impietatem adigeret necilli permitteret christum vita imitari tum liber hic sit solutus vt quicum libuerit se despondeat quòd si hoc christiano iure non liceret cogeretur fidelis infidelem suam comparem sequi vel inuitus repugnante natura viribus suis caelebs permanere magno cum animae suae periculo id ipsum paulus denegat inquiens quòd si eiusmodi frater aut soror seruituti non sit obnoxius ne que captus ne que venundatus sit ac si dicat aliis causis vbiconiuges vnâ commorantur vt debita coniugij beneuolentia id genus similibus alter alteri obligatus est nec sui 〈◊〉 est 〈◊〉 vbi alter alterum ad impiam vitam cogit vel ab altero discedit ibiverò non est captiuus ne que 〈◊〉 isti adhaerere porrò quòd si captiuus non tenetur liberatus manumissus 〈◊〉 despondere se alters potest velutisi matrimonio coniuncius sibimortem oppetiissit quid si 〈◊〉 coniugium non opportunè cederes vt alter alterum maritus vxorem vel è contra gentium morem adeo que impiè viuere cogeret vel si alter ab altero fugeret donec tertium 〈◊〉 quartum coniugium attingeretur dareturne viro toties 〈◊〉 ducere quoties alia eiusmodi vt iam dictum est esset vt decem velplures 〈◊〉 viuentes transfugas haberet et rursum licebitne vxori dectm aut plures qui iam omnes 〈◊〉 esse maritos responsio paulo non possumus obstruere o ne que cumillo 〈◊〉 eius doctrina quoties necessum fuerit vti volunt verba eius aperta sunt fratrem aut sororem liberos esse coniugij lege si alter discesserit vel cum hoc habitare non consenserit ne que vt semeltantùm stat hoc dicit sed liberum relinquit vt 7 imitaris verbis maritus proprij corporis potestatem non habet sed vxor et vxer sui corporis ius non habet sed maritus ne fraudetis vos mutuò ni vterque consenserit ecce 〈◊〉 hîc fraudem 〈◊〉 apostolus case last foure doctrine huddle vp together vpon false pretense master charke doth graunt sixt pointe lie think sound inough stand gospell touching first matrimonie much excellens virginitie master charke deede noteth certaine thinges respect whereof mariage excelleth virginitie confute yet refuseth stand vpon comparison saying good yet neither good mariage conteine virginitie respectes apostle noteth luther also doth acknowledge wherefore seeing apostle respect preferreth virginitie amadde man would affirme contrarie seeing apostle respectes doth preferre virginitie foolish wrangler quarelleth denieth mariage respect inferior virginitie haue nothing iouinian heluidius basilides whomesoeuer name condemned antiquitie affirming matrimonie paris esse merit cum virginitate equall dignitie virginitie respectesneither luther euer affirme contrarie owne wordes shall testifie quis que inquit suum donum habet alius sic alius verò sic hîc profitetur 〈◊〉 votum impleri non posse ne que velle deum cuique eximium exegis ad cap 7 epist 1 ad cor illud impartiri donum atque hunc textum tu intimis pectoris tui penetralibus recondas pleraque enim se complectitur ne que minus continentia matrimonium praedicat nam sicubi coniugium quis cum caelibatu conferat praestantius certè donum est 〈◊〉 attamen matrimonium itidem dei donum est inquit hoc locus paulus vt continentia ma etiam faeminae praestat attamen aequè vtille opus dei haec est coram deo enim omnia sunt aequalia quae inter sese alias distant quicquid condidit suum eum 〈◊〉 creasorem appellat dominum ne que quicquam alio sublimius eum nominat siue magnum siue paruum fuerit sic idem valet coram illo matrimonium virginitas nam vtrunque est donum creatura dei tametsi alterum alteri antecellas si quis inter wordes place large yealding reason doth highlie prefer mariage popish state speaking nothing virginitie continencie true chastitie shameles cauiller doth crie nemo igitur obiicies tua sententia coelelis permanebit sed quis que matrimonium contrahet quaeres huic paulino textui aduersaretur respondeo de spiriiuali nunc statu loquor ad matimonium comparato non de coelibatu status spiritualis nulli prorsum rei accommodus est sed perditissimus praestaret que neminem spiritualem quemque coniungtam esse porrò coelibatus vera continentia aliud est ac spiritualis status de hoc nihil omnino hîc paulus agit de vera n castitate loquitur nullus enim statuum impudentior ad libinem promptior est ecclesiastieo spirituali statu vt hodiernus dy contestatur quòd siex illis coelibes quidam essent non tamen vtuntur calibatu ad pauli institutum normam vt nequaquam castitas esse queat cuius hîc 〈◊〉 mentionē facit isti enim ex castitate meritum iactantiam magnificentiam coram deo hominib faciunt eafidunt idquod cūfide pugnat paulus verò exeafacilitatem quandam seruitutem ad verbum dei fidem effecit spiritualis verò status non ex labore suo viuit arcadico iumento segnior c thou wilt obiect thy sentēce therefore shall man remaine continent euerie one shal marie thing contrarie text saint paule answer speake spirituall state compared matrimonie continencie virginitie spirituall state suaui consolatione tanta tres voculas diabolus est mendax ignorassem ego 〈◊〉 nisi monuissetis vos eximij theologotati si papista essem omnium tentationum ruàis quem securum 〈◊〉 satan negligeres vt ipsos negligit indulgentes suis cupiditatibus c etiam talis gigas essem contra absentem hostem alacer fortis sed si vobis sustinendi essentictus diaboli audiendae disputationes non diu essetis cantilenam de ecclesia veteri recepto cantaturi equidem satis video dauid reliquis prophetis qu àm grauiter luctentur ingemiscunt certaminibus similibus contra diabolum horribilem impetum eius et christus ipse quamuis sine peccato propter no quantis lachrimis quibus angustiis agonizauit agonibus contra satanam vrget enim immensum corda nec 〈◊〉 ni repulsus verbo dei et ego planè persuasus sum emser um oecolampadium simile ictibus horribilib quassatio nib subitò extinctos esse nec n humanum cor horrer dum hunc ineffabilem impetum nisi deus illi adsit perferre potest satan enim 〈◊〉 oculus repente totam mentem terr oribus ac te nebris adobruit si nihil quàm hominem inermem verbo instructum inuenit quasi digitulo totum 〈◊〉 verum qui dem hoc est quód mendax sit sed eius mendacia non sunt simplicis artificis sed longè callidiora instructiora ad fallendum quàm humanus captus assequi possit ipse sic adoritur vt apprehendat aliquam solidam veritatem quae negarinon possit que eam adeo callidè versutè vrget acuit adeo speciose fucat suum mendacium vt fallat velcautissimos c vtî cogitatio illa quae iudae cor percussit vera tradidi sanguinem iustum hoc iudasnegare non poteratised hoc erat mendacium ergo est desperandum de gratia dei et tamen diabolus hoc mendacium hanc cogitationem tam violenter vrsit vt iudas eam vincere non possit sed desperaret proinde bone frater domine papista non mentitur satan quando accusat aut vrget magnitudinem peccati ibi enim habet duo inconuincibiles graues testis legem dei nostram propriam conscientiam non possum negare quòdreus summortis damnationis c sed ibi mentitur satan quando vltrà vrget vt desperem de gratia sicut cain dicebat maius est peccatum meum c et ibi tum opus est talus agone diuino caelesti auxilio vt vel srater adsit qui te consoletur promissionibus gratiae foris velintus corde spiritus sanctus verbum fratris erigat ac animet ac sustentet cor tuum vt possis sic apud 〈◊〉 statuere confessus quidem sum lege dei conuictus coram diabolo peccasse damnatum esse vt iudam sed verto ad christum cum petro respicio eius immensum beneficium meritum c ille omnem horrendam damnationem damnauit holie father answere laugh say art thou famous doctour knowest answere deuill dost thou know deuill lyer say giue great thankes worthie sweete comforse weightie matter three wordes deuill lyar haue knowne vntil except notable diuines taught papist vnexpert temptation whome satan would neglect beeing carles snorting neglecteth follow lust c giant also stout valiant enemie absent beare stripe deuill heare disputation longsing song church accustomed manner verilie doe see sufficientlie dauid rest prophet greeuouslie wrestle groone combates like deuill horrible violence christ himselfe although without sinne aboundance teares anguish siriue v conflictes satan vrgeth man heart exceedinglie ceaseth except driuen backe word god plainlie perswaded emser oecolampadius like sodendlie slaine wieh horrible stripe shaking rash iudge ment harte man cannot abide horrible vnspeakeable violence except god satan twinckling eie sodendlie ouerwhelmeth wholl minde terror darkenes finde nothing man vnarmed instructed word litle finger ouerwhelmeth true deed lyar lie simple craftes man much craftie prepared deceiue man capacitis comprehend doth sort set vpon man take holde sound truth denied vrgeth sharpeneth craftelie subtillie couereth cunninglie may deceiue take best heede c cogitation strake heart iudas true haue betraied innocent blood could iudas denie lie therefore must despaire grace god yet deuill vrged lie cogitation violentlie iudas able ouercome despaired therefore good brother sir papist deuill doth lie accuseth vrgeth greatenes sinne thereby hath two graue witness vnreproouable law god owne conscience denie haue sinned cannot denie sinne greate cannot denie guiltie death damnation c satan lyeth vrgeth dispaire grace cain said sinne greater c conflicte thou hast neede helpe god heauen either brother present may comforte thee outwardlie promise god holie ghost inwardlie thy heart thy brother word lift vp encourage comfort thy heart thou maist determine thus thy selfe haue deede confessed deuill beeing conuicted law god sinned condemned iudas turne selfe vnto christ peter looke backe infinite benefite merit c hath condemned horrible condemnation c reporte euerie indifferent reader whether luther doe speake spirituall conflicte tentation vnto desperation saying priuate masse knew idolatrie bodelie conference abolishing masse secondlie luther doth yeald perswasions deuill wherewith defender confesseth good euill men assaulted according difference obserued resisteth assault obtaineth victorie thorough christ let v heare argument defender bringeth prooue bodelie conference first confession tigurine caluenists false tigurines onelie reprooue luther intemperat inuectiues naming deuilles often wise defender concludeth ergo luther deuilles secondly saith euident conference spirituall deuilles preface wherein calleth frier right learned doctor according vaine pride wherewith saw puffed vp c reasonable man seeth presace title bitter scorne deuill flattering speach make readie receiue impression defender saith sound satan voice described place alledged censure none booke demissa angulari often alledged papist none de missa priuata vnctione sacerdotum appeareth verie wordes noted papist lib de missa angulari found boke de missa priuata c therefore sound satan voice papist dreame vpon matter defender would hide vnder title de missa angulari third reason luther confesseth fellowes haue beene slaine conference saith rash iudgement emser oecolampadius one papist protestant heaue hard word prooueth bodely conference terrible blowes shakinges speaketh bodelie busfeting satan saint paul speaketh doubteth 2 cor 12 7 spirituall buffeting satan man ouercome exceeding sorrow may suddenlie die except assisted comforted grace christ hominum conscientias per spiritum sanctum quanquam autem inter no hactenus non planè potuit conuenire num verum corpus 〈◊〉 sanguis christi pani ac vino corporaliter insit debebit nihilominus tamen passi sunt saluatores non quòd per totum annum excepta pentecoste ieiunare non liceat sed quòd aliud sit necessitate aliud voluntate munus offerre fast one lent fourtie day according tradition apostle wholl yeare time conuenient v make three lentes fourtie day fast yeare though three sauiours sussered lawfull yeare long except pentecostor fiftie day one thing offer gift necessitie thing doe free anelie learned well enough knowne signifie first graunt al chark said thinke gained nothing also confes law lord perfect sense wherein chark vsech wit law lord perfect therefore scripture cannot wrested afterward haue tolde v wordes vnde filed irreprehensible perfect answer latine greeke hebrue wordes 〈◊〉 much sense whatsoeuer irreprehensible vnspotted may also called perfect conclude doth prooue scripture perfect sense sort maie wrested peruerted say true false master chark maketh anie illation charge thus inferreth lawe god perfect ergo cannot wrested nose wax owne wordes scripture perfect manteineth perfection corruption right line sheweth selfe bewraieth crooked lawe wise man hath beene said may perfect cannot wrested like nose waxe anie sense wrester wil imagine vaine cauillation shall odious ridiculous al men much rather lawe god perfect though deuilles hell breake braines wrest peruertit yet neuer wrest like nose wax euerie side shape perfect sense scripture remaineth ful constant manifest haue spirit god yea euen iudge indifferentlie according right reason cont max arr lib 3 cap 14 waie charge master charke railing inueighing olde translation running careth whether forging careth reprehending careth whome yet discourse hath wordes olde translation doth goe alone wordes rayling running forging reprehending inueihing may conteined let ihe wiser sort iudge fooles learne wiser saith best translation differ olde translation aske best better good latine translation hath olde though none might good olde translation perceaue would acknowledge good set punishment doth reprooue lawes king kinges themselues whome crime transgression hath place wiselie said implous shall saie king thou doest vniustlie meanes sauiour graunt disciple dignitie power diuine nature trulie absurde sinnes may remitted haue holie ghost themselues remit retaine spirit dwelleth remitteth retaineth shalbe thinke two meanes first baptisme repeatence either induce men beleeve approoued holines life vnto baptisme diligentlie expill vnworthie child church doe offend rebuke indeede pardon repent paul commit fornicator among corinthian vnto destruction flesh spirit might saued receiued againe lest drowned greater sorrowe therefore spirit christ dwelling men performeth worke true god shall god nature naturallie possesseth power dignitie diuine nature hath excellent authority vpon lawe god last argument saint cyrill prooueth macidonian heretikes holie ghost verie god declareth neuer meant deifie priest authority proper god follow holie ghost god men authority remitting sin god hath wherefore followeth men onely instrument holie ghost speaketh declareth remission sin holie ghost subiect censure man intollerable blasphemie therefore father anie cal minister church protectours an̄d curers body soules cannot drawne anie meaning though deede deified made would saie partaker god nature worke god owne office world minister god appointed serue eternall saluation elect bodie soule order diuine exercise office holie ghost ambrose saith yet nothing communicated vnto man proper god simplie plainlie tearme principall pastours church halfe god meere men expresse perhaps meane author blasphemous verse writen pope refused nec deus e nec homo quasi neuter e inter vtrumque thou art neither god man neuter finde scripture ciuil prince called halfe god whole god execute parte god authoritie among men yet shall saie persons̄ therebie deified might well accounted blaspemous flatterer may see pudle toades familie loue crept vpon pretence spirit god dwelling men moste blasphemouslie affirme deifieth person make abilitie exercise workes god whereas power remitting sinnes graunted euen wicked priestes holie ghost dwelleth although hath bestowed giftes vpon make sufficient knowledge vtterance preach gospell allen saint ambrose helpeth matter long discourse reporte present purpose thus saith disputing nouarians assertion priestly cap 2 l 1 de poen dignitie assoyling sinnes qui spiritum sanctum accipit sic enim scriptum est accipite spiritum sanctum quorum remiseritis peccata remittuntur eis quorum retinueritis retenta sunt ergo qui soluere peccatum non potest non habet spiritum sanctum munus spiritus sancti est officium sacerdotis ius autem spiritus sancti soluendis ligandis que criminib est thatreceiueth holy ghost meaning taking order receiueth therewith power binde loose written receiue holie ghost whose sinnes doe forgiue forgiuen whose sinnes doe reseine reteined therefore cannot forgiue men offence haue holie ghost saie haue gift holie ghost giuen officer execution function christes behalfe gift holie ghost office priest proper right remission sinnes standeth holie ghost thus wrote saint ambrose heretikes time toucheth ouer ouercommeth falsehoode day minesterie man ioyneth god spirit diuine function cannot without blasphemie special contempt god contemned fvlke ambr helpeth matter neuera whit content mynistery seruise power subiect wil god wil halfe god men wil haue person deified wilbe able exercise proper work god ambr reasoneth nouatians would take vpō binde fallen would loose receue againe church vpon repētance signifying power one wel graunted church proper god reteine sinnes forgiue renounced one must renounce also reason proper right holie ghost doe one well nouatian heretikes found transgressours god commaundement willeth repentant loosed well obstinate offender bound ambrose therefore sayeth nothing deifying men person executing god commaundement mercy well iustice allen noxios arbitrentur cùm apud deum non sententia sacerdotum sed reorum vita quaeratur legimusin leuitico de leprosis vbi iubentur vt ostendant se sacerdotibus si lepram habuerint tunc sacerdote immundifierent non quòd sacerdotes leprosos faciunt immundos sed quòd habeant notitiam leprosi non leprosi possint discernere qui mundus quiuè immundus sit quomodo ergo ibi le prosum sacerdos mundum vel immundum facit sic hîc alligat vel soluit episcopus pres biter non eos qui insontes sunt vel noxij sed pro officio suo cùm peccatorum audierit varietates rietates scit qui ligandus sit quiue baptismum non egens lauacro quo peccatum non erat sed vt sacramento perennis daretur autoritas tanti virtutem operis nulla personarum acceptio commendaret quoniam remissio peccaterum siue per nouatians saie denie penance power remit sinnes earth respect maintenance honour due god whome onely reserue pardoning man sinnes deede none doe much iniury god glory breake commaundements make diuision charge commission giueth seeing lord iesus owne mouth spake word receiue ye holy ghost whose sinnes doe forgiue forgiuen whose sinnes holde beholden case honoureth god obeieth commaundement resisteth church obeieth well binding loosing thus litle looke whome charge giuen person may lawfullie god good leaue vse au l therefore church may lawfullie binde loose heresie attendant rightlie doe neither right onelie committed priest therefore church rightlie challengeth authoritie shee hath lawfull priest heresie cannot doe shee hath priest god cursed congregation thus said saint ambrose answere nouatians day say church behalfe like affected enemy christ honour while face scripture god word would seeme defend become sworne aduersaries honour open contemners commaundements holy ordinance saint ambrose taketh ground god ordinance priest remit sinnes bolde call contrarie doctrine heresie maketh principle neuer dishonoureth god man doe god giueth either commaundement commission doe behalfe taketh knowne trueth church god hath true lawfull priest shee may vpon christes warrant bath loose binde contrariwise heresie may well enough giue ouer right remission sinnes shee hath lightlie lawfull priest whome shee may practize fvlke first make vaine exclamation outcrie though heresie hath spoiled church treasure vnder pretence god glorie rhetoricall vamties wise men deride reason workes god cannot orderly benefi iallie vsed house god yet euer claimed themselues onlie order moste parte function christ church annexed order wherein passe forefather manner willinglie giue ouer wholl profession freelie without compulsion denie selues nouatus priestes denie sacrifice denie enioyne penance denie giue holie ghost either imposition handes chrisme solemne right god church short take nothing fellowes belongeth christianitie giue ouer selues briefllie conclude vp answere reason founded vpon nouatus principle touching god honour thus saie neuer derogateth god honour agreable god ordinance priest remit sinnes ordinance god declared therefore vse thereof doth derogate whit god honour againe great workes proper god remission sinnes practized apostle yet vsed bishop contr lid 6 ad deum conuerso peccata dimittuntur ab ii dimittuntur quibus ipse veraci conuersione coniungitur spiritus sanctus ea dimittit qui datus est omnibus sanctis sibi charitare cohaer entibus siue se nouerint corporaliter siue non similiter cum alicuius tenentur peccato ab eis tenentur quibus ille cordis prauitate disiungitur siue notis corporaliter siue ignotis omnes enim mali spiritualiter à bonis seiuncti sunt ecce hic dicit peccata dimitti vel teneri à sanctis viris tamen spiritum sanctum ea dimittere dicit quod maiori consideratione dignum est idem etiam dicit quod deus per se vel per sanctos suos tantùm dimittit peccata ait enim sic sacramentum gratiae dat deus etiam per malos ipsam vero gratiam non nisi per seipsum vel pcr sanctos suos ideo remissionem peccatorum vel per seipsum facit velper ipsius columbae membra quibus ait si quibus dimiseritis aimittentur ecce quàm varia à doctoribus traduntur super hactanta varietate quid tenendum hoc sane discere sentire possumus quod solus deus dimittit peccata retinet tamen ecclesiae contulit potestatem ligand soluendi sed aliter ipse soluit vel ligat aliter ecclesia ipse enim per se tantùm dimittit pecca tum quia enim animam mundat ab interiore macula à debito aeternae mortis soluit non autem hoc sacerdotibus concessit quibus tamen tribuit potestatem soluendi ligandi id est ostendendi homines ligatos vel solutos vnde dominus leprosū sanitati priùs per se restituit deinde ad sacerdotes misit quorum iudicio ostenderetur mundatus sinnes forgiuen truelie turned god forgiuen whome selfe true conuersion himselfe saint onelie remittesh sinnes thus saieth sacrament grace god giueth euen euilmen grace selfe himselfe causeth member doue whome saith ye shal forgiue shal forgiuen beholde diuerse thinges deliuered doctor concerning matter great variety holden truelie may saie thinke onely god forgiueth sinnes reteineth yet hath giuen power church binding loosing otherwise doth selfe bind loose firmissimè tene nullatenus dubites exeptis illis qui pro nomine christi suo sanguine baptizantur nullum hominem accepturum vitam aeternam qui non hîc à mali suis fuerit per penitentiam fidem que conuersus per sacramentum fidei penitentioe id est per baptismum liberatus maioribus quidem necessarium esse poenitentiam de mali suis agere fidem catholicam secundùm regulam veritatis tenere beleeue owne penitent sinne draw originally sacrament faith baptisme sufficient vnto saluation long age cannot ca pable reason yea semeth saying going imme diately speaketh next chapter first repentance men discretion might goe baptisme although true true repentance conuersion vnto god allen let man think true repentance anie effectuall remission sinnes follow appointed ordinance god remission sinnes dare bolde saie since time sauiours wordes tooke place nisi quis renatus fuerit except man borne againe water holie ghost enter kingdome heauen since word man saued without baptisme likewise since christ spake wordes whose sinnes forgiue forgiuen dare saie neuer man saued saued either contemneth neglecteth confession earnestlie seeketh fall relapse deadlie crime baptisme speake plainlie would haue thought earnestlie man ordinarilie saued without baptisme man euer baptisme committeth deadlie sinne saued without sacramentall confession earnest desire seeking maie seeme sharpe prooue true contemners god ordinance whensoeuer god worketh giftes grace among men anie ordinarie meanes appointed purpose great sinne seeke eitherwithout presume haue god handes otherwise hath charged high presumption contempt ordinance remission originall sinner properly pertaineth god mortall sinner yet christ hath instituted sacrament instrument meanes conuey singular benefit man would claime immediatly god owne hand therefore neglecteth sacrament baptisme would minister selfe without priest office neuer obtaine remission originall sinne adde high persumption disobedience god commaundement selfe without originall sinne damnable fvlke wise man thinketh true repentance effectuall remission sin dispise follow appointed ordinance god remission sin shalneuer prooue shrift fulgentius hard erewhile excepteth suffer martyredome christ name baptized water saint ambrose bolde affirme emperour valentinianus yonger slaine baptized vndoubtedlie saued comforting sister saith seueral oration made vpon death valentinian emperour sed audiui vos dolere quod nō acceperit sacramentū baptismatis dicitemihi quid aliud nobis est nisi voluntas nisi petitio atqui etiam dudum hoc votum habuit vt antequam italiam venisset initiaretur proximè baptizari se à velle significauit ideo prae coeteris carsis accipiendum putauit non habet ergo gratiam quam desiderauit non habet quam poposeit quia poposcit accepit vbi est illud iustus quacunque morse praeuentus fuerit anima eius refrigerio erit solue igitur pater sancte munus seruo tuo quod moses dum siritu vidit accepit quod dauid quia ex reuelatione cognouit emeruit solue inquam seruo tuo valentiniano munus quod concupiuit munus quod poposcit sanus robustus incolumis si affectus aegritudine distulisset tamen non penitus à tua misericordia esset alienus qui celeritate temporis esset non voluntate sraudatus solue ergo seruo tuo munus tuae gratiae quam ilie nunquam negauit qui ante diem mortis templorum priuilegia negauit insurgentibus quos reuereriposset astabat virorum catcrua gentilium supplicabat senatus non metuebat hominibus displicere christo qui habuit spiritum tuum quomodo non accepit gratiam tuam aut si quia solenniter non sunt celebrata mysteria hoc mouet ergo ne martyres si catechumeni fuerint coronentur non enim coronantur si non initiansur quòd si suo abluuntur sanguint hunc swa pieta abluit forgiue yet conclusion true whose sinnes minister gospell doth forgiue heare gospell forgiuen herofit doth follow euerie man bound shriue himselfe priest meane subiect priest iudgement minister gospell denounceth damnation impenitent obstinate sinner vnto sentence subiect plain tearmes christ owne wordes one truelie penitent sight god absolued sentence minister pronounceth name god forgiuenes truelie conuerted vnto god wherefore place necessitie auricular confession except draw wordes demonstratiue syllogismes suppose impossible selfe shall conscience confesse lesse whensoeuer dare goe touching difference shew betwixt priest office remitting sin baptisme penance standeth altogether vpon owne surmise without authoritie holie scripture minister ghospelis made much iudge whome admit whome refuse sacrament pronounce whose sin forgiuen whose reteined iudgement correction hath one neither punishment put apostle priest handes sinnes pardoned pardon punished punishment lesse sentence eternall damnation vnder obstinate vnrepentant sinner doe remaine iong continue obstinacie impenirencie therefore power iudiciarie exact examination penitent conuention god iudgement feare stage open offence vse predecessor day thing impediment confession doctor doth discharge penitent warranting priuate confession made without witnesse shall laie thing confessed charge open world enough though open order vsed counteth perfect better wherein saieth iob ashamed confesse faultes worlde much lesse christen men aboshed open themselues god meaning confession made god though discharged opening sinnes close consistory priest iudgement deede meaneth master first answered schoole men great exact iudgement magister quarto sententiarum steede publike confession made face church secret opening priest occupieth seat god therefore would neuer shame afore men would serue marie truth late libertie people set disordered demeanour foresaid deacon made cunning shepheard expert preacher vse wordes might winne moste worste least offence weake therefore speaketh warelie indifferentlie sometimes biddeth confesse god yet seuerall numbering euery sinnes while sermon saieth que oportebat maximè apud homines ea dicerc yet opened men might vnderstand meaning yet able reprehend word weake said vsed libertie loosing law nectatius day saint chrysostome much doe make submit themselues sinnes pastours soules wherein onelie great obtestations beginning sermon also continuall beating string confounded abashed vtter sinnes prooueth plainlie onelie purpose bring confession penance sacramentall done priestes ministerie chargeth weepe lament could doe rightlie thinges onelie inwardelie cogitation harte done could know make confession man know heretike maketh confession neither lamenteth neither doth penance sinnes haue remooued way god church wherebie thing wont done christ hath appointed done otherwise saie confesse themselues dailie god saint chysostomes flocke warrant counted sacramentall confessing except god priestes ministerie waie confession god hath appointed fvlke sure saint chrysostome went bring people necessity auricular cōfession standeth vpon owne assurance without warrant chrysostomes wordes cleane contrarie thereunto euen sermon quote requiring confession secret faultes made onelie god men sed confunderis erubescis peccata tua effari atqui oportebat maximè apud homines ea dicere inuulgare confusio enim est peccare non est confusio confiteri peccata nunc autem ne que necessariùm presentibus testibus confusio confiteri cogitatione fiat delictorum exquisitio absque teste sit hoc iudicium solus te deus confitentem videat deus qui non exprobat peccata tua sed soluit peccata propter confusionem nunquid sic grauaris retrocedis verùm ego scio quòd conscientia non sustinet sua delicta thou art ashamed abashed vtter thy sinnes yet thou oughtest moste declare publish men ashame sinne shame confesse thy sinnes neither necessarie confesse presence witness let examination thine offence made thought let iudgement without witnesse let god see thee making thy confession god casteth thy sinnes thy teeth seth thy sinnes thy shame arte thou greeued doe much goest backe yet know shy conscience cānot abide owne offence wordes man would thinke plaine enough necessitie auricular confession haue found moste impudent interpretation saie confessing god meaneth close consistory priest iudgement occupieth seate god exposition master sentence author schoolemen approouers verelie whosoeuer inuented whosoeuer haue alowed chrysostome crieth plainly meaning requireth examination thought alone iudgement without witnes cannot priest doe heare although count greater perfection make open confession men yet denieth necessarie commentarie vpon epistle hebrew cap 12 hom 30 plainlie hath exhorted men count sinnes seuerally god make hartie confession vnworthines addeth non 〈◊〉 tibi vt te prodas publicum ne que vt te pud alios accuses sed obedire te volo prophetae dicenti reuela domino taunt viam ante deum ergo confitere peccata apud verum iudicem cum oratione delicta tua pronuncia non lingua sed conscientiae tuae memoria tunc demum spera misericordiam te posse consequt sihabueris mente peccata tua contiuuò nunquam malum aduersus proximum corde retinebis say thee thou oughtest bewraie thy selfe abroad thou shouldest accuse thy selfe men haue thee obey prophet saying open thy wait lorde confesse thy sinnes therefore god prononnce thy offence true iudge praier thy tongue rememberance thy conscience hope thou maist obteine mercie thou shalt haue thy sinnes minde continuallie thou shalt neuer reieine euill thy heart thy neighbour must confesse selues consistorie true iudge neede pronounce tongue constience sinfull state close consistorie popish shrift without tongue priest know nothing yet doctor vpon 50 psal hom 2 writeth moste plainlie pecoata tua dictio vt deleas illa si confunderis elicui dicere quia peccasti dicito eaquotide anima tuas non dico vt confiter 〈◊〉 seruo tuo vt exprobret dicito deo qui curateoe haec enim si non dixeris ignorat ea deus nunquid à te vultea 〈◊〉 cùm faciehas ea practo erat cùm admitteres 〈◊〉 non erubuisti confiteri erubescis dicito 〈◊〉 v illa requiem habeas dicito ingemiscens lachrimans declare thy sinnes thou maiest 〈◊〉 thou ashamed declare thou hast sinned declare dailie thine owne soule doe saie thou oughtest confesse thy fellow seruent may cast thee teeth declare god doth heale thou shalt declare god ignorant would know thee thou didest present thou didest commit knew thou waste ashamed sinne art thou ashamed confesse declare thy sinnes life thou maist haue rest life declare groning weeping conscience could master sentence first man wrest word prooue plainlie onelie purpose bring men confession penance sacramentall meane popish shrift chargeth saie wcepe lament confesse sinnes could doe rightlie thinges onelie inwardlie cogitation heart done could knowthat make confession yes master allen beeing pastour ouerseer soules might know outward sinfull carelesse conuersation weepe lament confesse sinnes god dailie examine themselues chargeth would haue bene loose life therefore haue much obscurelie prooued purpose lest al chrysostomes onelie purpose driue people shrift beene necessarie institution christ holde would haue beene concealed though heauen earth runne together publishing thereof allen whosoeuer list see moste assured vndoubted meaning holie father touching confession apriest whereon stand longer aduersaries would man first easie man see man knoweth thing perteine man spirit man within wherefore man vse medicine disease manner whereof knoweth yea manie time cannot know whether man sicke made manifest hath dissicultie heale men great power shephearde doth sheepe may binde restraine meate burne cut power receiue health lieth offereth medicine sicke person wonderfull man saw saide corinthian lordes faith helper ioye moste required christian force reforme transgression sinne forreine iudges take malefactor vnder lawes doe shew great power ouer restreine vse manner compulsion perswasion must make one better power giuen v law restreine sinnes neither lawes gaue power haue vse seeing god crowneth necessitie abstaine wickednes voluntaryly refraine therfore neede great cunning sicke may perswaded willingly submit themselues vnto healing priestes thus much chrysostome nothing fauouring necessitie auricular confession rather denying mean wherby inward disease man may knowne except voluntarie extorted cōfession countie boniface speaketh publike fact cōmitted taking mā force church suspended augustine vntil acknowledge fault shew selfe penitent therefore saying drawne necessitie auricular shrift neither doth chrisostome vpon 20 iohn declare anie iudgement opinion thought necessarie man shriue himselfe priest vrge wordes priest doth lend voice hand farre prooue necessarie euery man confesse al secret fault priest set downe saith place least anie man hath vnderstand booke may suspect matter contained thererein toward purpose deed magna enim dignit sacerdotum quorumoun que c great dignitie priestes whose sinnes shall remit saith remitted wherefore paule saide obey gouernours subiect maie doe greatest honour thou lookest thine owne matter thou hast well ordered none charge laide vpon priest doe dispose owne life haue diligentlie cared thine shall thrust vngodlie 〈◊〉 sometime damned owne deedes except doe thing perteine vnto therefore seing see greatnes daunger embrace much beneuocence paule also signified saying doe watch shall giue account soules therefore much looued shal insult shal dispose thing wel long master ship good cheereful minde mariner also quiet begin hated thē greeued cannot likwise watch exercise cunning greeued shall trouble manie euills euen priest shall see reuerence due performed v shall able gouerne v well shall kill weakning handes although neuer great courage shall cast waues together selues vnderstād christ saith iewes vpon chaire moses scribe pharisies sit ye thing whatsoeuer shall saie must saie priestes set vpon chaire moses vpon chaire christ haue receiued doctrine wherefore paul saith embassadours chist though christ exhore v doe ye se men subiect prince worlde often time worse birthe life wisdome preferred better neuerthelesse men consider reuerence prince hath preferred person whatsoeuer man appoint one ouer v great feare god haue appointed anie man despise 〈◊〉 vexe innumerable contumely whereas forbidden iudge breethren whet tongue priest excuse thinges worthie se beame owne eye iudge seuerelse mote neighbour eye doest thou know thou prescribest thy selfe heauie iudgement thou iudgest another saie allowe vnworthie person taken priestes office hauing compassion weeping therefore iudged subiects although liue euillie vitiouslie thou looke well thy selfe thou shalt affend end aniething committed made asse speake gaue spirituall blessinges southsayer wrought dumbe mouth vncleane tongue balaam stumbling iewes much faithfull although priest naught god shall persorme thinges send holie spirite pure minde doeth therefore loose purenes grace worketh thing saith whether paule apollo cephas whatsoeuer priest goeth gift god alone exerciseth man wisdome grace appeereth lesse neither doe saie might liue slouthfullie least set ouer liue slouthfullie committed anie time procure euill selues speak priest neither angell archangell bring anie thing passe thinges giuen god father sonne holie ghost doeth thing priest giueth tongue handes iust malice man come saluation offended thinges considered let v seare god greatlie reuerence priestes honour giuen workes maie receiue priest sit chaire christ preach doctrine receiued confirming sacrament institution popish sacrament penance auricular confession speake nothing contrariwise shewe meanes priestes doe execute authoritie graunted remission sinnes namelie whole office ministerie consisting principallie preaching ministring sacrament giuing priuate absolution onelie principallie allen leaue fall great antiquitie learning whose iudgements also prooue onelie trueth doctrine also much vniformitie open ceremonie church olde vsed therefore like trueth thinges yet keepeth theodoritus therefore greeke author also doth plainelie diuinorum decret epi cap de poeniten insinuate onelie whole sacrameut euen ceremonie laying handes acte absolution sunt medicabilia saith etiam quae post baptismum fiunt vulnera medicabilia autem non 〈◊〉 olim per solam fidem data remissione sed per multas lachrymas fletus iciunium orationem laborem facti peccati quantitate moderatum quienim non sic affecti sunt eos nec admittere quidem didicimus nee diuina sunt manu impertienda nolite inquit dare sanctum canibus nec margarita porcis woundes made euen baptisme healed marie cannot remedied baptisme remission obteyned onelie faith must nowe cured teares weeping fasting praying penance measured quantitie nature fault whosoeuer qualified haue learned receiue grace neither holie giftes bestowed vpon hand giue saieth holie thinges dogges precious stone swine thus doth theodoritus allude also manner yet vsed sacrament remission giuen priestes worde hand cause saint aogustine calleth sacrament reconciliation vnderstood publike penitentes bounde loosed according qualitie offence greatnes repentance word behoueth haue receiued god power loosing binding consider qualitie sinne readines sinner vnto returning maie vse medicine fit disease lest determine sinne without difference erre health sick person disease sinne simple diuerse manie formes budding vp manie hurtfull branch euill spred farre wide creepeth farre vntill length withstandeth vertue healeth therefore shew skill hath spirituall art healing must diligentlie search hath sinned affected whether incline vnto health contrariwise manner familiarlie accustomed prouoke diseased looke whether himselfe obeyeth master whether sore minde doth encrease medicins laid mercie bestowed equall measure great regarde god gouernour pastorall care bring home wandring sheepe heale wounded serpent neither thrust downe hedlonges desperation loose raines vnto dissolution life contempt meanes well sharp medicine gentle withstand striue sore maie healed knoweth fruites repentance maie wiselie gouerne man called vnto heauenlie glorie therefore ought know kindes medicine well rigor pittie follow haue taken hand onelie vpper face figure deliuered saint basill hath taught v canon worde confession whereby necessitie confession maie inferred vpon men secret offence neither prooued penitentiarie priest abrogated nectarius euer restored schoolmes opinion bound follow pointes poperie saint bernard alloweth deede confession made vnto priest minister god necessitie thereof doth laie clogge men conscience like saie bede booke chapter quoted speaketh one adamanus scot hauing committed great wickednes youth considered greeuosnes fact great distrust minde comming priest whome hoped waie saluation might shewed vnto confessed guiltines desired giue counsell might auoid wrath god come manner come confession denie expedient quiered conscience al men bound example make perticuler rehersall sinnes priest haue remission beda neither el teacheth allen gregorie well liketh knoweth practize sacramentall confession pastorll cap 15 pastorall gregorij prescribeth priest god ghurch manie way seeke disease people soules according varietie admit put backe pardon punish yea plaine matter de poen dist 6 cap de sacer 5 chargeth priest exceeding grieuoslie punished anie case shall vtter penitentes confession anie parte thereof againe farre aboue holy leo great amending hard custome place italie epist 80 campania vsed touching publike confession priuat sin saieth reatus conscientiarum sussiciat solis sacerdotib indicari confessione secreta quamuis enim plenitudo fidei videtur esse laudabilis que propter dei timorem apud homines vide eundē ad theo dor iuli 〈◊〉 eruhescere non veretur tamen quia non omnium huiusmodi suntpeccata vt velint poenitentiam ed publicari remoueatur tam improbabilis cohsuetudo ne multi à poenitentiae remedijs arceantur dum aut erubescunt aut metuunt 〈◊〉 sais facta suareserare quibus possint legum constitutione per elli sufficit enim illa confessio quae primùm deo offertur tunc 〈◊〉 saccrdoti qui pro debitis confitentium precator accedit tunc enim demum piures ad poenitentiam potuerunt prouocari si populi auribus non publicetur conscientia confitentis enough guilt offence man conscience opened priest alone secret confession though foruour faith verie laudable content god sake ashamed men yet sinnes euerie man penitent would gladlie vtter openlie let raprobale custome abolished lest manie holden remedy penāce while either ashamed feare open deedes enimes might order law punished confession sufficient made first god priest also intercessour sinnes confesse might moe prouoked penance secret conscience confessed published eares people thus saith saint leo man time credit aduersaries would wish let saie priuat confession began lateran councell thing euer counted vsed necessarie decreed amending people sloth done euerie yeare lest receiued blessed sacrament truly maie saie euchariste receiuing thereof begune councell verie canon charge euerie man confessed commaundement giuen euerie man shall receiue yeare blessed sacrament litle care haue saie saie enough beguile skil nothing fvlke yf saint gregorie pastorall el written thing might make face necessitie auricular confession would haue set downe parte wordes least quoted booke chapter might finde trueth matter worke conteining three partes many chapter teacheth behauiour pastour preacher towardes alkindes person life doctrine auricular confession neuer worde therefore fly gratians decres gregory deed cited matter gregorie doth appeare therefore like one later gregory gregorie first whose workes long enough shew sentence saie priest may case vtter penitent confession glosse vpon text holdeth may account successours yet wee would wish time manie corruption superstition person ouer careful mainteine dignitie sea litle litle turned seat antichrist therefore ambition controlled generall councell chalcedon made bishop constantinople equall primacie honour authoritie although legate would haue withstoode vaine bishop allowed except lucentius pascasius deputy may still saie necessitie auricular confession came first lateran councel cannot prooue inioyned vpon necessitie although vsed voluntarily thought verie conuenient allen holde vpward holie prosper giueth good euidence time touching practize confession needefull recourse priest release sinnes de vita con tempt sundrie remedy sheweth euerie sore man soule much mooueth al christian confesse sinnes aduertising daunger thereof keepe close thus saith illi quorum peccata humanam notitiam latent nec ab ipsis confessa nec ab 〈◊〉 publicata si ea confiteri aut emendare noluerint deum quem habent testem ipsum habituri sunt vltorem et quid eis prodest humanum vitare iudicium cùm si malo suo permanserint ituri sunt aeternum 〈◊〉 retribuente supplicium saie men whose sinnes secret confessed themselues lib 2 c 7 published men confesse correct shall haue god iust reuenger whome haue record wickednes better escape man verdict continue wickednes iust iudgement god shall goe euerlasting punishment afterwarde chapter exceeding much considered giueth priest carefull admonition hauing committed deadelie sinne doe notwistanding without confession vttering holde ministery blessed sacrament would sight men noted worthie case damneth himselfe god whose heauie indignation cannot auoide while ashamed vtter sinnes vnto men fvlke prosper hath nothing necessitie auricular confession rather speaketh neither confesse secret sinnes amende liues without confession men shewing continue sinne vaine shall auoide iudgement man fall eternall iudgement god followeth immediatelie quòd si ipsi iudices fiant veluti suae iniquttatis vltores huius se voluntariam poenam seuerissimae animaduersionis exerceant temporalibus poenis mutabunt aeterna supplicia lachrimis ex vera cordis compunctione fluentibus restinguent aeterna ignis incendia become iudges themselues reuengers owne iniquitie doe exercise hereupon themselues punishment moste seuere correction temporall paine shall change eternall punishment teares flowing true compunction heart shall quench burning eternall fire wordes declare meanes without confession secret faultes men maie obteine remission auoide euerlasting punishment thing yet cleare carefull admonition giueth priest communicate without confession least wise secret repentance punishment enioyned themselues wordes quapropter deum sibi facilius placabunt illi qui non humano conuict iudicio sed vltrò crimen cognoscunt qui aut proprijs illorum confessionibus produnt aut 〈◊〉 alijs quoles occulti sint ipsi se voluntariae excommunication sententiam ferant ab altari cui ministrabant non animo sed officio seperati vitam tanquam mortuam plangunt certi quòd reconciliato sibi efficacis poenitentiae fructibus deo non solùm amissa recipiunt sed etiam ciues supernae ciuitatis effecti ad gaudia sempiterna perueniant wherefore men shall easilie pacifie god vnto themselues conuicted man iudgement owne accord acknowledge fault either bewraie owne confession though men know secret themselues giue sentence voluntarie excommunication themselues seperated minde office altar serued doe bewaile life dead beeing certeine god reconciled ftuites effectuall repentance doe onelie recouer haue lost also made toward ende origen hath necessitie popish shrift priest first place li peri archon 3 cap 1 wil rehearse somewhat large reader maie iudge plaine necessitie auricular confession purpose declare men saide forsaken god hi verò qui nondum se tanta constantia neque tanto affectu offerunt deo neque parati sunt accedentes adseruitutem dei praeparare animus suos ad tentationem derelinqui dicuntur à deo id est non erudiri pro eo quod ad erudiendum parati non sunt posterum sine dubio tempus eorum dispensatione vel curatione dilata qui vti que quid à deo consequentur ignorant nisi priùs ad beneficia consequenda per desiderium venerint quod demum fiet si quis ante seipsum cognoscat sentiat quid sibi desit quid sibi deest à quo quaerere vel debeat vel possit intelligat qui enim non intellexerit prius infirmitatem vel aegritudinem suam medicum quaerere nescit vel certè cùm receperit sanitatem non egerit gratias medico quoniam non priùs periculum sui languoris cognouit si qui non priùs animae suae vitia peccatorum suoruns cognouerit mala ac proprij oris confessione prodiderit purgari absolui que non paterit ne ignoret sibi per gratiam concessum fuisse quod possidet diuinam liberalitatem proprium bonum putet quae ret sine dubio arrogantiam generes elationem denuo ei causa sit ruinae quodetiam de diabolo sentiendum est qui primitus honores suos proprios non à deo datos esse credidit quos habebat tunc cùm immaculatus erat impleta est eo illa sententia quae dicit quòd omnis qui se exaltat humiliabitur yet offèr themselues god great constancie great affection neither readie come seruice god prepare themselues vnto temptation saide forsaken god taught prepared taught disposing healing without doubt deferred vnto time come trulie knowe shall obteine god except come first desire vnto obteining benefit thing length shall brought passe man know himselfe first feele wanting vnderstande whome ought maie seeke wanting vnto shall first vnderstand owne infirmity sicknes cannot seeke phisitian anie also shall first knowe vice soule euills sinnes bewraie confession owne mouth cannot purged absolued least ignorant thing graunted grace possesseth thinketh liberalitie god owne goodnes thing without doubt maie gender arrogancie pride maie againe cause falling thing also muste thinke deuill first beleeue honour vndefiled owne giuen god sentence fulfilled saith euerie one exalteth himselfe shalbe brought lowe reasonable man discourse woulde gather necessitie shrift priest certaine writer speaketh acknowledgeing sinnes god without obteine pardon remission handes confessing remission sinnes saieth seauen kindes remission sinnes gospell namelie 1 baptisme 2 martyrdome 3 almes giuing 4 inforgiuing men 5 conuerting sinner 6 abundance charitie seauenth expresseth wordes rehearse verie vnperfectlie translate falselie est adhuc septima licet dura laboriosa per poanitentiam remissio peccatorum cùm lauat peccator lachrimis stratum suum fiunt ei lachrimae suae pane die ac nocte cùm nou erubescit sacerdoti domini indicare peccatum suum quaerere medecinam secundùm cum qui ait dixi pronunciabo aduersum iniustitiam meam domino turemisisti impietatem cordis mei quo impletur illud quod apostolus dicit si quis autem infirmatur vocet presbyteros ecclesiae imponant ei manus vngenteseum oleo nomine domini oratio fidei saluabit infirmum si peccatis fuerit remittentur ei yet seauenth kinde remission sinnes though hard painefull repentance sinner washeth bed teares teares made foode daie night ashamed declare sinne priest lorde seeke medecine according saith haue saide confession passe ouer alter wordes folowing secundùm cum qui ait initio sicut scriptum est appareth borowed place man allegation notebooke negligentlie gathered doe cite owne reading matter answere gennadius maketh mention anie workes extant time dyonisius areopagita therefore certaine counterfaited long vnder name allen stand vpon euerie point greeueth much matter fruitfull one worthie witnes actes strong aduentures defence prince countrie fareth though fought vnder truthes baner boast victorie heresie whereas haue serued heresie done indeuor trueth striuing nothing much heresie might change name trueth voutchsafe consider litle labour haue bin encountred chased field able discerne trueth heresie giue trueth true name trueth heresie right name heresie let v see great matter champion trueth hath brought passe first christ power giuen apostle successours remit sinnes victorie indeed soone archiued neuer withstood tlitle manner power executed sentence definitiue declaratiue according god man meanes exercised preaching gospell murmering word wherein trueth controulleth heresie haue broughtnothing fortifie error secondlie saie confession stituted christ yet haue word
